bestBHT.bht: Paul's charge to Timothy is presented with great solemnity as he invokes the presence of God, Christ Jesus, and the elect angels. This weighty adjuration underscores the need for impartiality and careful judgment, urging Timothy to guard against condemning based on mere accusations or personal bias. The inclusion of the elect angels emphasizes their active involvement and sympathy in earthly affairs. In light of this, Timothy is reminded to faithfully uphold God's principles, just as the holy angels faithfully fulfill their own roles.

Henry Alford: I adjure thee in the presence of God, and of Christ Jesus...and of the elect angels."
He forbids two things: the condemning through trusting to the mere credit of accusers, or doing this same through malice, without accurate enquiry.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I charge thee—rather as Greek, 'I adjure thee'; so it ought to be translated (2 Timothy 4:1).
Lord—omitted in the oldest manuscripts God the Father, and Christ the Son, will testify against thee if thou disregardest my injunction.
Angels take part by action and sympathy in the affairs of the earth.
Albert Barnes: Paul gives this charge as in the presence of God, of the Redeemer, and of the elect angels, and wishes to secure that sense of its solemnity which must arise from the presence of such holy witnesses.

No one can prove that the angels, and that the departed spirits of holy men, are not witnesses of what we do... as if the eye of a departed father, mother, or sister were fixed upon us, and as if we were encompassed by all the holy beings of heaven.
Let there be entire impartiality in all cases... all, of whatever rank, color, sex, or age, have equal rights.
Marvin Vincent: Elect angels... may refer to all angels, as special objects of divine complacency.
Observe... the Pauline sense of keeping the law.
Without preferring one before another... without prejudice.
John Calvin: Let us remember that, in the person of Timothy, all pastors are admonished, and that Timothy is armed, as with a shield, against wicked desires, which not infrequently occasion much trouble even to some excellent persons.
Therefore, he [Paul] places God before the eyes of Timothy, that he may know that he ought to execute his office not less conscientiously than if he were in the presence of God and of his angels.

They [the elect angels] are present as spectators, because they have been commanded to take care of the Church. And, indeed, he must be worse than stupid, and must have a heart of stone, whose indolence and carelessness are not shaken off by this single consideration, that the government of the Church is under the eye of God and the angels.
Philip Schaff: The solemnity of the adjuration here...implies a latent fear that the youth, the asceticism, the sensitiveness of Timothy might lead him beyond the line of strictly judicial action."

The meaning of the adjective is not quite clear. In one sense all good angels were among God’s elect; but the word is probably used of those who were chosen specially for ministering to the righteous judgments of God."
Without preferring one before another. A mistranslation. Read, as above, 'without prejudice' in the sense of 'without pre-judging.'
Archibald T. Robertson: Elect in the sense of the holy angels who kept their own principality and who did not sin.
First aorist active subjunctive of φυλασσω, to guard, to keep... Subfinal use of ινα.
Late and rare word (from προκινω, to judge beforehand), three times in the papyri, here only in N.T. 'Without prejudgment.'
John Gill: I charge thee before God....in whose place and stead, the judges of the earth, both civil and ecclesiastical, stand; and to whom they are accountable for the judgment they pass on men and things.
But this is a spurious account, and not to be credited; nor was it an ancient tradition of the Jews, that there were seven principal angels.

The angels are not sworn by, or appealed unto; only in their presence is this solemn charge given; and it may be observed, that even inanimate creatures, the heavens and the earth, are sometimes called upon as witnesses.
John Wesley: I charge thee before God...the apostle looks through his own labours, and even through time itself, and seems to stand as one already in eternity.
That thou observe these things without prejudging...passing no sentence till the cause is fully heard.
Or partiality...for or against any one.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, Paul addresses Timothy with a strong adjuration, invoking God, Christ Jesus, and the elect angels as witnesses. Through this charge, Paul emphasizes the importance of impartiality and careful judgment in Timothy's role as a pastor. The presence of the elect angels serves as a reminder that they actively participate in and show sympathy towards earthly affairs. Paul urges Timothy to keep the law faithfully and without prejudice, just as the holy angels had kept their principality and abstained from sin. Overall, Paul's admonition highlights the gravity of Timothy's responsibilities as a leader in the church, emphasizing the need for diligent and unbiased adherence to God's principles.

Paul's charge to Timothy carries great weight as he adjures him in the presence of God, Christ Jesus, and the elect angels. This solemn appeal highlights the necessity for impartiality and careful judgment. The elect angels, known for their obedient service, serve as a reminder to Timothy of the importance of faithful adherence to God's principles. By avoiding prejudice and following the law faithfully, Timothy can fulfill his role as a pastor and exhibit the same commitment as the holy angels who keep their own principality and refrain from sin.

In this significant charge to Timothy, Paul appeals to him in the presence of God, Christ Jesus, and the elect angels. Through this solemn adjuration, Paul emphasizes the importance of impartiality and careful judgment, cautioning against hasty condemnation or prejudging. The presence of the elect angels serves as a reminder of their active participation in earthly affairs and their commitment to divine principles. Timothy is urged to emulate their obedience and faithfulness in carrying out his responsibilities as a pastor.

Paul's charge to Timothy in the presence of God, Christ Jesus, and the elect angels carries a weighty significance. He urges Timothy to avoid condemning others based on mere accusations or personal malice, emphasizing impartiality and accuracy in his judgments. This adjuration highlights the active involvement and sympathy of the elect angels in earthly affairs, as they fulfill their important role as ministers chosen by God. Paul's instruction to Timothy underscores the need to faithfully keep the law, guarding against prejudice and ensuring equitable treatment for all.
